column1: These decisions are based on the statement made by Lord Denning in Macfoy v. United
Africa Company Limited [(1961) 3 All E.R. 1169 at 1172]:
“If an act is void, then it is in law a nullity. It is not only bad, but incurably bad. There
is no need for an order of the court to set it aside. It is automatically null and void
without more ado, though it is sometimes convenient to have the court declare it
to be so. And every proceeding which is founded on it is also bad and incurably bad.
You cannot put something on nothing and expect it to stay there. It will collapse.”
